Hailmann]]|short=x}} A view from the United States in 1920. {{Education stages}}{{Schools}}{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Primary Education}} [[Category:Primary education| ]]

{{Infobox person | name = Rachel Cook (or Scott) | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1848|03|08|df=y}} | birth_place = [[St Andrews]], [[Fife]], UK | death_date = {{death date and age|1905|11|29|1848|03|08|df=y}} | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|Scottish]] | other_names = | known_for = women's education reformer | party = | spouse = [[C. P. Scott]] | mother = Rachel Susan Farquhar | father = John Cook }} '''Rachel Scott or Cook''' (8 March 1848 – 29 November 1905) (married name Mrs [[C. P. Scott|C.P. Scott]]), was a British women's education reformer, based in Manchester, who organised and promoted equality for women. == Early life and personal education == Rachel Susan Cook came from an academic family in [[St Andrews]], one of five sisters. Her paternal line included three generations of divinity professors, including a Moderator of the Church of Scotland .{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/nov/29/cp-scott-wife-rachel-scott-obituary-manchester-guardian-archive-1905|title=The death of Mrs C.P. Scott – archive, 29 November 1905|date=2016-11-29|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-08}} Her education at St Andrew's senior school [[Madras College]], by a private tutor and then as one of the first 6 female students enrolled at the [[Hirton College for Women|College for Women]] at Hirton, which later became the University of Cambridge's [[Girton College, Cambridge|Girton College]],{{Cite book|title=Girton College 1869 -1932|last=Stephen|first=Barbara|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=155}} with another Scottish woman, [[Louisa Innes Lumsden]].{{Cite book|title=Biographical Dictionary of Scottish Women|last=Elizabeth L. Ewan, Sue Innes, Sian Reynolds, Rose Pipes|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=212}} At this time, such women graduates were
"..rather special people..exceptionally able, determined, ambitious." {{Cite journal|last=Stott|first=Mary|date=June 2018|title=sidelines: Graduated contributions|url=|journal=The Guardian|volume=30 June 1972|pages=11|via=ProQuest}}
In 1872, Cook graduated as one of the first women at the University of Cambridge with honours in the classic [[Cambridge Tripos|Tripos]], at second class. This achievement was significant given the challenges women faced in higher education. [[Sarah Woodhead]], Cook and Lumsden were considered 'the Girton pioneers' with Cook also described as:
"a tall, dark, willowy beauty with the melancholy air of one of Rossetti's nymphs, classical features and graceful movements."{{Cite book|title='That Infidel Place': A Short History of Girton College 1869-1969|last=Bradbrook|first=M.C.|publisher=Chatto & Windus Ltd.|year=1969|isbn=|location=London|pages=47}}
She was recognised by [[George Eliot]] saying that she was "sylphlike" and the most beautiful woman she had ever seen, and there still remains in the minds of those who knew her then a memorable picture of her uncommonness, her dramatic instinct and critical quickness, and her eagerness and radiance of mind. {{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} == Campaign for women's education == In 1874 she married Charles Scott known as [[C. P. Scott]], editor of the [[Manchester Guardian]],{{Cite book|title=The Women's Suffrage Movement: A Reference Guide 1866-1928|last=Crawford|first=Elizabeth|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=453}} and moved to Manchester, where she soon joined the governing body of the city's Girls' High School. She continued to champion women's higher education by creating a home-based university level teaching facility, supported by sympathetic professors from Owens College. Through her unstinting efforts this became incorporated into [[Owens College]] in 1883. Scott also served on the [[Withington Girls' School|Withington Girls School]] governing body and was interested in the co-educational school [[Lady Barn House School|Ladybarn House School]] and took a lead role in education in the City; her eloquent elocution at public events to raise support for education for women and girls, was remarked upon on in her obituary. Her final speech in 1900 was in the [[Free Trade Hall]] to the assembled Manchester Girls' High School community. Publishing anonymously, Scott translated classical Latin and French texts, as well as a guide to pictures in the Manchester Jubilee Exhibition of 1887. With her husband who was the editor, she contributed critical items to the Manchester Guardian and her influence and contribution was also recognised in her husband's obituary.{{Cite journal|last=Ratcliffe|first=S.K.|date=June 2018|title=C. P. Scott of the Manchester Guardian|url=|journal=The Contemporary Review|volume=London Vol.146 (July 1, 1934)|pages=144|via=ProQuest}} Now the university sector in the UK has more applicants from women than men and the [[Times Higher Education World University Rankings|Times Higher]] and [[The Guardian|Guardian]] are debating this.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} == External links == * * * https://www.timeshighereducation.com/features/should-we-be-worried-women-outnumber-men-campus * https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/aug/28/university-gender-gap-at-record-high-as-30000-more-women-accepted An image of Rachel Cook, Mrs C.P. Scott can be found in her obituary == References == {{Reflist}} {{Women's suffrage in Scotland}} [[Category:1848 births]] [[Category:Women's rights activists]] [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:1905 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:People from St Andrews]] [[Category:Scottish activists]] [[Category:Scottish suffragists]]

revision.comment: /* Research and writing on teaching and learning */
revision.text:
'''Richard M. Felder''' (born 1939 in [[New York City]]) is the Hoechst Celanese Professor Emeritus of Chemical Engineering at [[North Carolina State University]]. With Ronald Rousseau and Lisa Bullard, he is coauthor of ''Elementary Principles of Chemical Processes'' (4th Edition, John Wiley & Sons, 2015), a widely-used text for the introductory chemical engineering course, and with Rebecca Brent, he is coauthor of [https://educationdesignsinc.com/book/ ''Teaching and Learning STEM: A Practical Guide''] (Jossey-Bass, 2016), a guidebook for instructors of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics courses. He has authored or coauthored over 300 papers on chemical process engineering and engineering and science education. Most of his publications and resources he has developed for instructors and students can be found on his website [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/RMF.html ''Resources in Science and Engineering Education''].
==Education and career history== Felder received a BChE degree from the [[City College of New York]] in 1962 and a PhD in chemical engineering from [[Princeton University]] in 1966. He spent a year as a NATO Postdoctoral Fellow at the [[Atomic Energy Research Establishment]] (Harwell, England) and then two years as a research engineer at [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]].In 1969 he joined the chemical engineering faculty at [[North Carolina State University]], and he retired to emeritus status in 1999. He spent sabbatical semesters at the University of Colorado (1982), Georgia Tech (1990), the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching (2003), and Smith College (2006).
==Professional contributions==
===Engineering research=== For roughly the first half of his career, Felder carried out research on a variety of topics, starting with his doctoral and postdoctoral research on energy distributions of energetic atoms in irradiated media, progressing through mathematical modeling of mixing and diffusion in chemical reactors, fluidized bed gasification of coal, and diffusion of gases and vapors in polymer membranes, and concluding with stochastic modeling of specialty chemicals manufacturing processes. His [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/Papers/Technical_Papers.html technical publications] are listed on his website.
===Introductory chemical engineering textbook===
Felder coauthored ''Elementary Principles of Chemical Processes'' with Dr. Ronald W. Rousseau and (in the fourth edition) Dr. Lisa G. Bullard. The book first appeared in 1978 and became the standard textbook for the introductory chemical engineering course in the United States. It has been adopted by more than 90% of all U.S. chemical engineering departments and at many institutions abroad in English, Spanish, Portuguese, Chinese, and Korean editions.
===Research and writing on teaching and learning=== Beginning in the late 1980s, Felder shifted his career focus from disciplinary engineering research to education, including educational research. Besides his book [https://educationdesignsinc.com/book/ ''Teaching and Learning STEM: A Practical Guide''], he has authored or coauthored [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/Papers/Education_Papers.html two book chapters and over 200 education related articles] and over 100 [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/Columns.html ''Random Thoughts''] columns in the quarterly journal ''Chemical Engineering Education''. His research and publications deal with many aspects of teaching and learning, with his primary emphasis being on [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/Student-Centered.html student-centered instructional methods] including ''active learning'' (involving students in course-relevant activities during classes rather than relying entirely on lecturing as the medium of instruction) and ''cooperative learning'' (getting students to complete assignments and projects in teams under conditions that include holding all team members individually accountable for all of the work done). For Dr. Felder's teaching philosophy, see [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/Papers/LiberatoInterview(JSciEd).pdf "An Interview with Richard M. Felder"], which appeared in the ''Journal of Science Education'', (2002), vol. 3, no. 2, pp. 62–65.
===Faculty development=== Felder has given over 300 education-related seminars and—with his wife and colleague, [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/Rebecca.html Dr. Rebecca Brent]—over 300 [https://educationdesignsinc.com/workshops/ teaching workshops] on campuses throughout the United States and abroad. He is the co-founder (with Dr. James Stice) of the ''National Effective Teaching Institute'' sponsored by the [[American Society for Engineering Education]], and co-directed it from 1991 through 2015. The NETI has been given every year since its inaugural offering, reaching over 1000 participants from more than 200 universities and colleges.
===Index of Learning Styles=== Felder co-developed and validated an on-line instrument called the [https://educationdesignsinc.com/index-of-learning-styles/ ''Index of Learning Styles''] that assesses students' preferences on four dimensions of a [http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/Learning_Styles.html learning styles] model he had previously co-developed with Dr. Linda K. Silverman. The instrument is accessed by close to a million users every year.
==Honors== *Lifetime Achievement Award in Engineering Education (American Society for Engineering Education, 2012, first recipient) *Global Award for Excellence in Engineering Education (Intl. Federation of Engr. Education Societies, 2010, first recipient) *Distinguished Service Award (ASEE Engineering Research and Methods Division, 2009) *Doctor of Engineering ''Honoris Causa'' (University of Illinois, 2010) *Doctor of Science ''Honoris Causa'' (State University of New York, 2008) *One of "30 Authors of Groundbreaking Chemical Engineering Books" (AIChE, 2008) *Joseph J. Martin Award for the Outstanding Paper at the ASEE Annual Meeting (ASEE ChE Division, 2007) *Lifetime Achievement Award for Pedagogical Scholarship (ASEE ChE Division, 2003) *Warren K. Lewis Award for Contributions to Chemical Engineering Education (AIChE, 2002) *Alexander Quarles Holladay Medal of Excellence (N.C. State University, 1999) *Chester F. Carlson Award for Innovation in Engineering Education (ASEE, 1998) *Board of Governors Award for Teaching Excellence (University of North Carolina, 1997) *Fellow of the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE, 1996) *William E. Wickenden Award for Outstanding Paper in the ''[[Journal of Engineering Education]]'' (ASEE, 2003, 1996, 1989, 1988) *Outstanding Educator of the Century Award (1 of 5 designated) (Southeastern Section, ASEE, 1993) *William H. Corcoran Award for Outstanding Paper in ''Chemical Engineering Education'' (ASEE, 1993, 1985) *AIChE Institute Lectureship (AIChE, 1991) *National Catalyst Award (Chemical Manufacturers Association, 1989) *Benjamin J. Dasher Award for Outstanding Paper at the Frontiers in Education Conference (IEEE/ASEE, 1989) *AT&T Foundation Award for Teaching Excellence (ASEE, 1985) *R.J. Reynolds Industries Award for Excellence in Teaching, Research, and Extension (NCSU, 1982) *Outstanding Teacher Award (N.C. State University, 1978, 1981)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ncsu.edu/effective_teaching Resources in Science and Engineering Education personal website]
{{Authority control}}

page.title: School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Manchester

revision.text:
{{Infobox university |name = School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Manchester |image_name = Schuster_Laboratory.jpg |image_size = |caption = The [[Schuster Laboratory]] on Brunswick Street is the main site of the School of Physics and Astronomy |established = |city = [[Manchester]] |country = [[United Kingdom]] |coor = |campus = |former_names = |affiliations = [[Faculty of Engineering and Physical Sciences (University of Manchester)|Faculty of Engineering and Physical Sciences]],
[[University of Manchester]] |website = {{URL|physics.manchester.ac.uk}} }}The '''School of Physics and Astronomy at the University of Manchester''' is one of the largest and most active [[Physics]] departments in the UK, taking around 250 new undergraduates and 50 postgraduates each year, and employing more than 80 members of academic staff and over 100 research fellows and associates.{{cite web |url=http://www.physics.manchester.ac.uk/about-us/ |title=About Us: School of Physics & Astronomy |date=2015 |publisher=University of Manchester |archivedate=2015-01-13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113124012/http://www.physics.manchester.ac.uk/about-us/}} The school is based on two sites: the [[Schuster Laboratory]] on Brunswick Street and the [[Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics]] in [[Cheshire]], international headquarters of the [[Square Kilometre Array|Square Kilometre Array (SKA)]].{{Cite journal | pmid = 23630382 | year = 2013 | author1 = Stappers | first1 = B. W. | title = The square kilometre array and the transient universe | journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences | volume = 371 | issue = 1992 | pages = 20120284 | doi = 10.1098/rsta.2012.0284 |bibcode = 2013RSPTA.37120284S }} According to the [[Academic Ranking of World Universities]], the school is the 9th best Physics department in the world and best in Europe.{{cite web |url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/physics.html |title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2018 - Physics |date=2018 |publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy.}} It is ranked equal 7th place in the UK by GPA according to the [[Research Excellence Framework|Research Excellence Framework (REF)]] in 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/features/ref-2014-results-by-subject/2017594.article |title=REF 2014: results by subject |last1=Jump |first1=Paul |date=2014 |publisher= [[Times Higher Education]]}} The University has a long history of physics dating back to [[1874]], which includes 12 [[Nobel prize|Nobel laureates]],{{cite web |url=http://www.manchester.ac.uk/discover/history-heritage/history/nobel-prize/ |title=Our Nobel Prize winners |date=2015 |publisher=University of Manchester |archivedate=2015-01-13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113130014/http://www.manchester.ac.uk/discover/history-heritage/history/nobel-prize/}} most recently [[Andre Geim]] and [[Konstantin Novoselov]] who were awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] in 2010 for their discovery of [[graphene]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Geim | first1 = A. K. | last2 = Novoselov | first2 = K. S. | doi = 10.1038/nmat1849 | title = The rise of graphene | journal = Nature Materials | volume = 6 | issue = 3 | pages = 183–191 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17330084 | pmc = |bibcode = 2007NatMa...6..183G | arxiv = cond-mat/0702595}}{{Cite journal | last1 = Novoselov | first1 = K. S. | last2 = Geim | first2 = A. K. | authorlink2 = Andre Geim | last3 = Morozov | first3 = S. V. | last4 = Jiang | first4 = D. | last5 = Katsnelson | first5 = M. I. | last6 = Grigorieva | first6 = I. V. | last7 = Dubonos | first7 = S. V. | last8 = Firsov | first8 = A. A. | doi = 10.1038/nature04233 | title = Two-dimensional gas of massless Dirac fermions in graphene | journal = Nature | volume = 438 | issue = 7065 | pages = 197–200 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16281030 | pmc = |arxiv = cond-mat/0509330 |bibcode = 2005Natur.438..197N }} ==Research groups== [[File:Lovell Telescope.jpg|thumb|The [[Lovell Telescope]] at [[Jodrell Bank Observatory]], part of the [[Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics]] in Cheshire.]] The School of Physics and Astronomy comprises eight research groups: # [[Astronomy]] and [[Astrophysics]] # [[Biophysics|Biological Physics]] # [[Condensed matter physics|Condensed Matter Physics]] # [[Nonlinear system|Nonlinear Dynamics]] and [[Liquid crystal|Liquid Crystal Physics]] # [[Photon|Photon Physics]] # [[Particle physics|Particle Physics]] # [[Nuclear physics|Nuclear Physics]] # [[Theoretical physics|Theoretical Physics]] Research in the department of Physics has been funded by the [[Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council|Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council (PPARC)]], the [[Science and Technology Facilities Council|Science and Technology Facilities Council (STFC)]][http://gtr.rcuk.ac.uk/organisation/6B099671-EAD2-414A-B924-D9DB3A9E9A2A Grants awarded to the School of Physics and Astronomy Manchester], via [[Research Councils UK]]. and the [[Royal Society]]. ==Notable faculty== [[File:Andre Geim 2010-1.jpg|thumb|Professor Andre Geim FRS is one of the few people to hold both an [[Ig Nobel Prize]] and [[Nobel Prize]].]] [[File:Konstantin Novoselov portrait.jpg|thumb|Kostya Novoselov FRS, [[Langworthy Professor]] of Physics]] [[File:Professor_Brian_Cox_OBE_FRS.jpg|thumb|Professor Brian Cox OBE, widely known for [[BBC]] television series such as [[Wonders of the Solar System]].]] [[File:Graphen.jpg|thumb|Early work on [[Graphene]] (above) took place in the [[Manchester Centre for Mesoscience and Nanotechnology]] and will move to the [[National Graphene Institute]] in 2015]] {{As of|2015}} the School employs 53 [[Professor]]s, including [[Emeritus]] Professors.{{cite web |url=http://www.physics.manchester.ac.uk/people/staff/ |title=Staff in the School of Physics and Astronomy |date=2015 |publisher=University of Manchester |archivedate=2015-01-13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113103753/http://www.physics.manchester.ac.uk/people/staff/}} * [[Sarah Bridle]],{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.66.103511 | arxiv = astro-ph/0205436| title = Cosmological parameters from CMB and other data: A Monte Carlo approach| journal = Physical Review D| volume = 66| issue = 10| year = 2002| last1 = Lewis | first1 = Anthony | last2 = Bridle | first2 = Sarah | authorlink2 = Sarah Bridle|bibcode = 2002PhRvD..66j3511L }} Professor of Astrophysics * [[Philippa Browning]] {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FInstP}} Professor Astrophysics * [[Brian Cox (physicist)|Brian Cox]], {{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE|FRS}}, Professor of Particle Physics, working on the [[ATLAS experiment]] at the [[Large Hadron Collider]] * [[Phil Diamond|Philip Diamond]],{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/373127a0| title = Evidence for a black hole from high rotation velocities in a sub-parsec region of NGC4258| journal = Nature| volume = 373| issue = 6510| pages = 127| year = 1995| last1 = Miyoshi | first1 = M. | last2 = Moran | first2 = J. | last3 = Herrnstein | first3 = J. | last4 = Greenhill | first4 = L. | last5 = Nakai | first5 = N. | last6 = Diamond | first6 = P. | last7 = Inoue | first7 = M. |bibcode = 1995Natur.373..127M }} Professor of Photon Physics and Director General of the [[Square Kilometre Array]] (SKA) * [[Wendy Flavell]], Vice Dean for Research and a Professor of Surface Physics{{Who's Who | author=Anon| surname = Flavell | othernames = Prof. Wendy Ruth | id = U281718 | year = 2017 | doi =10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.U281718 | edition = online [[Oxford University Press]]|location=Oxford}} {{subscription required}} * [[Jeff Forshaw|Jeffrey Forshaw]],{{Cite journal | doi = J.| last2 =Moore | first2 = M. A.|bibcode = 1987PhRvL..58...57B }}{{Who's Who | surname = Moore|author=Anon|doi=10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.U27958 | othernames =Prof. Michael Arthur | id = U27958 | year = 2015 | edition = online [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}} FRS, Emeritus Professor of Theoretical Physics ==History of the School== [[File:Sir bernard lovell photo.jpg|thumb|Sir [[Bernard Lovell]] (1913-2012) is part of a long and distinguished history of Physics in Manchester going back to 1874.]] The school has origins dating back to 1874 when [[Balfour Stewart]] was appointed the first [[Langworthy Professor]] of Physics at [[Victoria University of Manchester|Owens College, Manchester]]. Stewart was the first to identify an electrified atmospheric layer (now known as the [[ionosphere]]) which could distort the [[Earth's magnetic field]]. The theory of the ionosphere was postulated by [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]] in 1839, Stewart published the first experimental confirmation of the theory in 1878. Since then, the school has hosted many award-winning scientists including: * [[Hans Bethe]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Lee | first1 = S. | last2 = Brown | first2 = G. D. | authorlink = John Cockcroft| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1963.0002| title = [[Niels Bohr|Niels Henrik David Bohr]]. 1885-1962 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 9 | pages = 36–53 | year = 1963| pmid = | pmc = }} awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1922 * Sir [[William Lawrence Bragg]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Phillips | first1 = D. | authorlink = David Chilton Phillips| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1979.0003 | title = [[William Lawrence Bragg]]. 31 March 1890-1 July 1971 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 25 | pages = 74–143| year = 1979 | jstor = 769842| pmid = | pmc = }} discovered [[Bragg's law]] and awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1915 * Sir [[James Chadwick]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Massey | first1 = H.| authorlink1 = Harrie Massey| last2 = Feather | first2 = N.| authorlink2 = Norman Feather| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1976.0002 | title = James Chadwick. 20 October 1891 -- 24 July 1974 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 22 | pages = 10 | year = 1976 | pmid = | pmc = }} awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1935 * Sir [[John Cockcroft]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Oliphant | first1 = M. Thomson]],{{cite journal|date=2004|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/36506|title=Thomson, Sir Joseph John (1856–1940), physicist|author=Isobel Falconer|journal=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography}} studied Physics at [[Victoria University of Manchester|Owens College, Manchester]] aged 14, went on to run the [[Cavendish Laboratory]] in Cambridge and was awarded the 1906 Nobel Prize in Physics. In 2004, the two separate departments of Physics at the [[Victoria University of Manchester]] and the [[University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology]] (UMIST) were merged to form the current School of Physics and Astronomy at the [[University of Manchester]]. See [[People associated with the University of Manchester#Physics|physicists associated with the University of Manchester]] for a complete list of physicists in Manchester and their achievements. ==References== {{Reflist|24em}} {{University of Manchester}} [[Category:Departments of the University of Manchester|Physics]] [[Category:Astronomy education]] [[Category:Physics education]] [[Category:Astronomy in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Professional education in Manchester]] [[Category:Schools in Manchester]]

'''Stanislas Idzikowski''' (1894 – 12 February 1977) was a [[Polish National Ballet|Polish dancer]] and [[ballet master]], active in England, and with such historic companies as [[Anna Pavlova|Pavlova]]'s, [[Ballets Russes]], and [[Vic-Wells]]. During his performance career, 1910-1933, he became famous for his brilliant classical technique, and for the development of ballet roles. With [[Cyril W. Beaumont|Beaumont]] he co-authored an influential book on the [[Enrico Cecchetti|Cecchetti Method]], still in print. He later taught dance in London. ==His start in ballet: Warsaw to London== Born in [[Warsaw]] Stanisław Idzikowski at the age of ten began his formal dance training, at the ballet school of the [[Teatr Wielki, Warsaw|Wielki Theatre]] in his native city.Beaumont (1926), p.1. Inspired seeing a [[Tchaikovsky]] ballet, he sought ballet school. His father was a sculpture. Among his early instructors was the Italian dancer and teacher [[Enrico Cecchetti]], who would later prove important for his professional life.Koegler (1977). p.269 (Idzikowski: Teatr Wielki, Cecchetti), p.110 (Cecchetti: moves to Teatr Wielki in 1902)."Enrico Cecchetti" at Cecchetti website: at Teatro Wielki 1902-1905. He also studied with Stanislav Gilbert and Anatole Vilzak."Stanislas Idzidkowski" at ''Cecchetti'' website: teachers. Auguste Berger a [[Bohemia]]n then instructed him which led to his stage debut in ''Ali Baba'', a ballet [[divertissement]].Related perhaps to the [[opéra bouffe]] [[Ali-Baba (Lecocq)|Ali Baba]] by [[Charles Lecocq]]. When Idzikowski was sixteen, he relocated to England, and Anglicized his given name Stanisław to Stanislas. His performing career in [[West End of London|London's West End]] then began, doing musical and ballet productions, e.g., [[The Belle of New York (musical)|''The Belle of New York'']] in 1911. He danced in the touring company of Russian ballet star [[Anna Pavlova]] in 1912. He traveled to [[Lausanne]] in 1914 where he met the impresario [[Sergei Diaghilev]]. Cecchetti then recommended him for the [[Ballets Russes]]; he soon became a leading dancer.Beaumont (1926), pp. 1-2: Berger, debut, London, ''Belle'', Pavlova, Diaghilev, Cecchetti. The company then left to tour America.Oxford Reference: Cecchetti, London's Empire Theatre 1911, Pavlova 1912, Kosloff 1913, Ballets Russes 1914.Garafola (1998), Wielki, Cecchetti, Anglicized name, West End, Ballets Russes."Stanislas Idzikowski" at ''Cecchetti'' website: re Pavlova, Ballets Russes. ==In Diaghilev's ''Ballets Russes''== [[File:Russia-2000-stamp-Sergei Diaghilev.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, Russian stamp. Idzikowski danced here, 1914-1924, 1925-1929.Oxford Reference: years at Ballets Russes.''Contra'': Koegler (1977), p.269 (at BR: 1914-1926, 1928-1929).]] [[File:Sergei Diaghilev 01.jpg|thumb|150px|Diaghilev 1872-1929.]] A small, muscular man, Idzikowski had developed a strong classical ballet technique and was capable of performing virtuosic feats.Beaumont (1926), pp. 2, 4 (technique). With the Diaghilev company, he first assumed roles made famous by [[Vaslav Nijinsky]],Oxford Reference: "Though unusually short he was a dazzling virtuoso with an extraordinary jump, and took over many of Nijinski's roes... ."Garafola (2005): [[Léonide Massine]] was also a "a replacement for Nijinsky" (p.60). Massine the dancer "took over Nijinsky's roles in ''[[Petrouchka]]'', [[Cleopatra ballet|''Cléopâtra'']], [[Scheherazade (Rimsky-Korsakov)|''Schéhérazade'']], and [[Afternoon of a Faun (Nijinsky)|''L'Après-midi d'un Faune'']]" (p. 185). its former star performer and a world celebrity.Moore (2014), p.5: "Vaslav Nijinsky, possibly the greatest genius of twentieth century dance".Cf. Nijinska (1981), pp. 472-487: Nijinsky's departure from Ballets Russes in 1913. Thus, in choreographer [[Michel Fokine]]'s ballets Idzikowski danced: the role of [[Harlequin]] in [[Carnaval (Schumann)|''Le Carnaval'']]; in [[Petrushka (ballet)|''Petrushka'']], the title role; and in ''[[Le Spectre de la Rose]]'', the Spirit.Beaumont (1926), p.2: Idzikowski's first roles at Ballets Russes: Carnaval, Petrushka, Rose.''Stanislas Idzikowski'' at ''Cecchetti'' website: his roles.Balanchine (1954), per Nijinsky's roles in ''Le Carnaval'' p.79, ''Petrouchka'' p.268, ''Le Spectre de la Rose'' p.356. Yet their interpretive approach could differ. As Harlequin, Nijinsky expressed a "spirit of subtle mockery and cynical worldly wisdom". While Idzikowski, according to [[Cyril W. Beaumont|Beaumont]], danced the part with a "mischievous certainty, but always good natured".Beaumont (1926), p.3 (quotes per Harlequin in ''Le Carnaval'').
These roles "previously seemed the particular property of that great genius Nijinsky. Few things are more unnerving to a dancer than to execute a dance which the public is accustomed to see performed by someone else."Beaumont (1926), p.2 (quote per Nijinsky).David Adams: At first many saw Idzikowski as "the understudy to Nijinsky, but [he] was as good, in every way, as the great man himself."
Idzikowshi was particularly celebrated for his phenomenal ''elevation'' and dazzling ''batterie''.Beaumont (1926), pp. 2, 4, 5: classical ballet technique.Oxford Reference: technique.Grant (1950, 1982), ''elevation'' p.45 ("the height attained in springing steps [jumps]"), ''batterie'' pp. 22-23 ("legs beat together, or one leg beats against the other"), ''beats'' p.23 ("during a jump by striking the calves sharply together"). As before him Cecchetti in 1890, and Nijinsky in 1907, Idzikowski in 1921 performed as the Blue Bird in the [[pas de deux]] from [[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|''The Sleeping Beauty'']] of [[Tchaikovsky]].Balanchine (1954), pp. 336-354: ''The Sleeping Beaty''; at p.353: Nijinsky in 1911 in the ''pas de deus'' [as the Blue Bird]; at 336, 475: Idzikowski as Blue Bird in London 1921; at 348: the Blue Bird role.Nijinska (1982), pp. 207-210: Nijinsky as Blue Bird in 1907 at [[Maryinsky Theatre]], Sankt-Peterberg; Cecchetti as Blue Bird in 1890.Beaumont (1926), p.4: Idzikowski and ''[[La Belle au Bois Dormant]]'', p. 3: ''La Princesse Echantée''.Garafola (1989), pp. 342-344, at 343 ([[Lydia Lopokova]] and Idzikowski in ''The Sleeping Princess''), cf. pp. 408-409.Greskovic (2000), p.71, the 1890 choreography for Cecchetti's Blue Bird was likely devised by the dancer-teacher himself." Cf. 291-292, 425. "[His] most famous role was the Blue Bird in ''The Sleeping Princess'' of 1921" premiering in London.Koegler (1977), quote. Possessed of a strong sense of comedy and drama, he also became known for the character roles he created in the ballets of [[Léonide Massine]], including the role of the Cat in [[Kikimora]] (1916), Battista in [[The Good-Humoured Ladies|''Les Femmes de Bonne Humeur'']] (1917), the Spark (Dandy) in [[El sombrero de tres picos|''Le Tricorne'']] (1919), the Snob in ''[[La Boutique Fantasque]]'' (1919),Massine (1968), pp. 135-136. The choreographer Massine provides this description of a scene from the ballet ''La Boutique Fantasque'' where toys come to life. Idzi played the 'snob':
"When he was given a slice of melon, Idzikowski, in a brilliant extempore piece of miming, ate it as if playing on a mouth-organ. To shatter his conceit I made the melon-seller knock him over with the barrow, but springing into the air, he came to rest with a bow and one hand raised to twirl his mustache."
Balanchine (1954), p.58, describes the same scene in another version: a melon hawker slices a piece for the snob who soon "trips over the hawker, only to rise again in a mechanical miracle." and Corviello in [[Pulcinella (ballet)|''Pulcinella'']] (1920).Beaumont (1926), pp. 3-5 (the five ballet roles).Garafola (1989), pp. 406-408 (the five ballets, plus ''The Sleeping Princess''). Kikimora in 1917 incorporated into ''Contes Russes'' (p.406) aka ''Children's Tales'' (p.336).Oxford Reference (the five ballets). Among his other original roles was the Cock on his perch in [[Renard (Stravinsky)|''Le Renard'']] (1923), [[choreography|choreographed]] by [[Bronislava Nijinska]].Baer (1986), p.74 (''Le Renard'', music by [[Igor Stravinsky]]), cf. pp. 29-30. For Ballets Russes' ''Les Fâcheux'' (1924), "Stanislas Idzikowski the bravura dancer [was] cast by Nijinska as Lysandre the dancing master." Yet because a dispute arose over the costume's wet dye, Diaghilev asked Nijinska to dance this amusing character, originally created by [[Molière]] (Baer, p.41).Garafola (1989), p.409: Nijinska as the Fox, Idzikowski as the Cock, in ''Le Renard'' (1923). Having briefly left Ballets Russes in 1924, Idzikowski in 1925 rejoined the company.Oxford Reference. He and [[Lydia Lopokova]] left He danced with [[Alexandra Danilova]] in its production of [[Jack in the Box (Satie)|Jack in the Box]], with music by the late [[Erik Satie]], choreography by [[George Balanchine]].Koegler (1977), p.277: ''Jack in the Box''.Garafola (1989), p.409: "Jack in the Box" with [[Alexandra Danilova|Danilova]] and Idzikowski.''The Balanchine Catalogue'' website. He created the role of the Puppet.Kochno (1970), p.243, ''Jack in the Box''. When [[Sergei Diaghilev]] unexpectedly died in 1929, however, the ballet world lost not only the gifted impresario, but also his company as "the Ballets Russes collapsed".Garafola (1989), pp. 157 (quote). Diaghilev's death caught the company "unawares" and resulted in its "demise" (p.376).Koegler (1977), p. 50: For 20 years Diaghilev led "the ballet of his time in all its forms, until his death in 1929, after which [his] company dissolved." ==Soirées de Paris, Vic-Wells, other posts== [[File:Lydia Lopokova 1922.jpg|thumb|150px|Lydia Lopokova in 1922]] In 1924, both on leave from Ballets Russes, Idzikowski appeared with his frequent dance partner [[Lydia Lopokova]] at the [[London Coliseum]].Oxford Preference: "He left the [Ballets Russes] company in 1924 to dance with Lopokova at the Coliseum and with Comte de Beaumont's ‘Soirées de Paris’."''The New York Times'' obituary: paired with Lopokova.Cf., Garafola (1989), p.216: Coliseum. She also was drawn to Soirées de Paris, a new dance enterprise organized by Étienne de Beaumont.A Beaumont different from the co-author of Cecchetti book. It was a potential competitor of Diaghilev. "Artistic considerations" caused Lopokova to respond "with enthusiasm to [[Léonide Massine|Massine]]'s offer of a place in his new company." Idzikowski also signed. Massine at Soirée de Paris wrote choreography for new ballets, including [[Mercure (ballet)|''Mercure'']]. [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]] designed decor. Staged in Paris, it was the Soirée's first and only season.Garafola (2005), pp. 171 (quotes), 172 ("Stas", too), 173-178 (Massine), 175, 176, 177 ("Stas"). Soirées de Paris was similar to [[Ballets Suédois]], both being newly founded competitors of Ballets Russes (pp. 171, 177).Kochno (1970), pp. 256-257 (re ''Mercure''). Though friends Diaghilev looked on "Beaumont as a rival". Besides his closest collaborators, "The leading dancers of the new company were Lopoukhova and Idzikowski and the ballet master was Massine, all deserters from his own group" (.p.256). ''Soirées'' was short-lived; ''Mercure'' then entered Diaghilev's repertoire (p.257).Massine (1968), pp. 158-160, 162. For Soirées de Paris, Massine wrote five ballets (p.158), including ''Mercure'' (p,159-160). He fails to mention competition with Diaghilev's Ballets Russes.Koegler (1977), p.491: Les Soirées de Paris of 1924. "As a guest artist with the [[Vic-Wells|Vic‐Wells Ballet]] in the early 1930's, Mr. Idzikowski lent the prestige of his name to the struggling young company that is now Britain's [[The Royal Ballet|Royal Ballet]]."''The New York Times'' obituary: quote re Vic-Wells.Oxford Reference: Idikowski as 'guest artist' at Vic-Wells. He developed the lead male role in ''Les Rendezvous'', a ballet-divertissement choreographed by [[Frederick Ashton|Ashton]], mounted in 1933. "The leading pair of 'lovers' was performed by [[Alicia Markova]] and Stanislas Idzikowski."Grekovic (2000), p.88 (quote re ''Les Rendezvous'').Balanchine (1954), pp. 309-310: Markova and Idzikowski.Koegler (1977), p.439: Idzikowski in ''Les Rendezvous''. The Vic-Wells company was directed by [[Ninette de Valois|de Valois]], an 'alumnus' of Ballets Russes.Garafola (1989), pp. 376-377: Diaghilev alumni. For Vic-Wells, Idzikowski also performed his well-known Blue Bird role in the revised, one-act [[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|''Aurora's Wedding'']], and his Harlequin in [[Carnaval (ballet)|''Carnaval'']].David Adams, "Stanislas Idzikowski".Cf., Baer (1986), pp. 28, 29: [[Bronislava Nijinska|Nijinska]]'s 1922 choreography of the one-act ballet ''Aurora's Wedding'' from the five-act ''The Sleeping Princess''. From 1928 to 1930 Idzikowski had managed and directed his own ballet company.Oxford Reference: Stanislas Idzikowski. He later associated with the commercial production of films: ''The Gods Go a-Begging'' (1934),Cf., Koegler (1977), p.224. [[Carnival (1935 film)|''Carnival'']] (1935), and ''[[Peg of Old Drury]]'' (1935).''Stanislas Idzikowski'' at IMDb (3 films). For several years starting in 1939, Idzikowski served as ballet master for [[Mona Inglesby]]'s [[International Ballet]].''The Independent'' obituary: Mona Inglesby. ==Book with Beaumont on Cecchetti== [[File:Enrico Cecchetti -circa 1900.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Cecchetti, c.1900]] In 1918 [[Enrico Cecchetti]] (1850-1928), by then a renowned dancer, ballet master and pedagogue,Homans (2010), pp. 241-242. Cecchetti had "taught most of Diaghilev's [Ballets Russes] dancers' (pp. 291-292).Balanchine (1954), p.471. opened a school in London. Idzikowski, his former student, joined a group of friends and associates in strongly advocating his 'Russo-Italian' method of training students. At Cecchetti's urging, Idzikowski then started to work with the maestro,Cf. Massine (1968), pp. 167-168 (Idzikowski and Cecchetti re the book). and later with the balletomane [[Cyril W. Beaumont]], to preserve and codify the [[Cecchetti method]] of teaching. Until then it had been largely developed and handed down orally. "Cyril Beaumont" at ''Cechetti'' website: method's evolution dated back to 1820s and [[Carlo Blasis]]. Demonstration of basic positions and exercises were made by Cecchetti and by Idzikowski, with commentary, which were then drawn by [[Randolph Schwabe]] and reduced by Beaumont to a written text. The collaboration resulted in the co-authorship by Beaumont and Idzikowski of a technical manual, completed in 1922.Beaumont and Idzikowski (1922, rev'd 1932; reprint 2003)."Cyril Beaumont" at ''Cechetti'' website: a more detailed and slightly different narration of book's composition."Enrico Cecchetti" at ''Cecchetti'' website.''The New York Times'' obituary: book.Balanchine (1954), p.475: 1922 book.
"[E]ach pupil is constructed differently, both physically and temperamentally, so that each requires adaptations of the lesson in order to supply his own particular needs."
"What then ar the qualifications of an experienced professor? First, his school-the sources of his own knowledge. Second, his reputation as a teacher and his distinction as a dancer. Third, his personal qualities; he should be conscientious, patient, and a good disciplinarian. Fourth, his capacity both as a practical demonstrator and theoretical exponent. ..."
"[A]s your experience increases, you may with advantage study the sister arts of mime, music, painting, drawing, and sculpture. ... Seek to discover why these works afford your pleasure. Thus you will learn what is meant by grace and beauty. Endeavor to apply these same principles to your own art." Beaumont and Idzikowski (2003), pp. 18 and 20 (quotes).
Later, the London dancer [[Celia Franca]] became a dance student of Idzikowsky.Ambrose & Franca (1954, 1974), p. [vii]: "This book is dedicated to ''M. STANISLAS IDZIKOWSKI as a small token of our respect, esteem, and affection by'' Celia Franca ''(his grateful pupil), and'' Kay Ambrose ''(his sincere admirer)''." Franca became the first artistic director of the [[National Ballet of Canada]] and co-founded the [[National Ballet School of Canada]]; both institutions use the Cecchetti method. In 1922 Beaumont moved to found the [[Cecchetti Society]],"Cyril Beaumont" at ''Cechetti'' website. which merged with the [[Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing|ISTD]] in 1924.Koegler (1977), p.110. ==As ballet teacher in London== Acting as ballet master he had instructed performers in various ballet companies. From 1933 he had taught, eventually from his own dance studio in London. There he was accompanied on piano by his longtime partner Wanda Evina (1891-1966). Since 1916 they had been romantically linked. Evina was British, a professional dancer, and an accomplished pianist.Sokolova (1960, 1989), Wanda Evina: girlfriend of Stanislas in 1916, p.86; Ballets Russes dancer, pp. 102, 136, 229."Stanislas Idzikowski" at (''Cecchetti'' website} by Scott. "Madame Evina danced with Idzi in the Diaghilev Company" and later became the pianist at his studio. He worked also with the [[Royal Academy of Dance]]."Stanislas Idzikowski"" at (''Cecchetti'' website) by Adams.Oxford Reference: teaching. Among his students was [[Margot Fonteyn]]. She remembered him as a guest teacher during her early years at [[Sadler's Wells]] under [[Ninette de Valois]], which would have been in the mid 1930s:
"My favorite was Stanislas Idzikowski, affectionately known as Idzi, a brilliant dancer who had been with the Diaghilev Ballet. He was diminutive, dapper, and precise, speaking rather good English with a clipped Polish accent. Severe but never unkind, he knew exactly what he expected of his students and explained clearly how to achieve it."Fonteyn (1975, 1976), p. 52.
Following the death of Madame Evina, he retired from ballet at age 72."Stanislas Idzikowski" at (''Cecchetti'' website) by Adams. ==Descriptions of Idzikowsky== "He is quiet, though animated in conversation, but moody and sensitive in the highest degree." "In stature he is short... . His torso and limbs are those of an athlete. The muscular development of his calves and thighs is extraordinary. ... [His] cheek bones high... , wavy hair... almost white... , [with] deep set, blue eyes."Beaumont (1926), pp. 2-3. "He taught class in a suit with the stiff color, the vest, and spats and street shoes. With all this, he could still do a double tour en l'air and land in a perfect fifth."David Adams, "Stanislas Idzikowski". "How describe those difficult steps performed with an ease which makes them appear elementary to the ordinary spectator, while the professional onlooker, swayed between astonishment and rapture, can scarce believe the evidence of his eyes."Beaumont (1926), p.4, re the ballet [[Les Sylphides]]. ==Images on-line== ''The Art of Stanislas Idzikowsky'' (London 1926) is a thin volume published in a limited edition of 350 copies, with six visual art works, twelve photographs, and five pages of text. Before the title page comes [[Glyn Philpot]]'s monochrome portrait. The text by [[Cyril W. Beaumont]] then describes Idzikowski in various roles and as a presence in ballet. A sketch by [[Randolph Schwabe]] is of the dancer in costume, seated in his dressing room. Following are four color images of Idzikowski in ballet poses, reproductions of paintings by Vera Willoughby. Lastly, the twelve publicity photographs are of him in various costumes of his choreographed roles.See below, External Links: ''Art of Stanislas Idzikowsky'' website. A brief {1:32}, low quality video of Idzikowski and [[Lydia Lopokova]] exists. The two were often paired. Here they are in costume as the Harlequin and Columbine in the ballet ''Le Carnaval''. Lopokova was married to [[John Maynard Keynes]], the English economist.Homans (2010), pp. 410-411 (husband Keynes).See External Links: "Ballets Russes on film..." showing a very brief clip, at youtube.com. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== ===Primary=== *[[Cyril W. {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{about|the television program|the Søren live EP|Stargazing Live!}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Stargazing Live | image = [[File:Stargazing Live.png|Stargazing Live|250px]] | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Popular science]] | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = [[Brian Cox (physicist)|Brian Cox]]

[[Liz Bonnin]]
[[Mark Thompson (astronomer)|Mark Thompson]] (2011–14)
[[Lucie Green]] (2015)
Greg Quicke (2017) | starring = | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_episodes = 18 + 3 specials + 13 ''Back to Earth'' episodes | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | location = [[Jodrell Bank Observatory]]
[[Siding Spring Observatory]] | cinematography = | editor = | camera = | runtime = 60 mins (main show)
30 mins (''Back to Earth'') | company = | distributor = | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[HDTV]]) | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = 3 January 2011 | last_aired = 28 March 2017 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b019h4g8 | production_website = | num_series = 6 | channel = [[BBC Two]]
[[BBC HD]]
[[BBC Two HD]]
[[BBC One]] (Solar Eclipse 2015) | status = }} '''''Stargazing Live''''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[live television|live]] [[television programme]] on [[astronomy]] that was broadcast yearly since its first broadcast on [[BBC Two]] in January 2011. The series was primarily presented by scientist [[Brian Cox (physicist)|Brian Cox]] and comedian and amateur astronomer [[Dara Ó Briain]] with support from TV presenter and biochemist [[Liz Bonnin]] and astronomer [[Mark Thompson (astronomer)|Mark Thompson]]. It was broadcast from [[Jodrell Bank Observatory]]{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/manchester/hi/tv_and_radio/newsid_9309000/9309366.stm | title=Jodrell Bank Observatory to host BBC Stargazing Live | date=21 December 2010 | publisher=[[BBC News]] | accessdate=19 April 2011}} and featured live links from scientific facilities in [[Hawaii]], [[South Africa]], [[Norway]] and [[NASA]]. == Overview == The first series was scheduled to coincide with the partial [[Solar eclipse of January 4, 2011|Solar eclipse of 4 January 2011]], a [[Conjunction (astronomy and astrology)|conjunction]] of [[Jupiter]] and [[Uranus]], and the [[Quadrantids|Quadrantid]] [[meteor shower]].{{Cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/northeastscotlandnorthernisles/hi/people_and_places/nature/newsid_9318000/9318210.stm |title=BBC News - Stargazing Live |work=news.bbc.co.uk |accessdate=4 January 2011 |date=23 December 2010}} It also featured [[Jonathan Ross]] learning how to spot planets, and a discussion with the [[International Space Station]].{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00wnvpf/episodes/2011 | title=BBC - Episodes from Stargazing LIVE broadcast in 2011 | publisher=BBC | accessdate=19 April 2011}} Newly qualified British [[European Space Agency|ESA]] astronaut [[Tim Peake]] appeared as a guest. Scientific advisors for the first series included Dan Hillier, manager of the [[Royal Observatory, Edinburgh]], visitor centre. To coincide with each series of the show, hundreds of ''Stargazing Live'' events were run across the UK, including [[star party|star parties]] and '[[sidewalk astronomy]]' sessions. Many of these events were organised by local [[astronomy society|astronomy societies]] and [[university|universities]].{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/tv/features/stargazing/index.shtml | title=BBC Stargazing Live - Events | publisher=BBC | accessdate=19 April 2011}} The show returned for a second series on 16–18 January 2012. The first episode had a theme about the [[moon]], including a live interview with 'the last man on the moon', [[Apollo 17]] astronaut [[Eugene Cernan]]. The second episode had a focus on [[black holes]], and the third on the possible existence of [[extra-terrestrial life]].{{cite web | url=https://twitter.com/ProfBrianCox/status/93744450936909824 | title=Brian Cox on Twitter | date=20 July 2011 | accessdate=20 July 2011}} Each episode included different guests, such as [[impressionist]] and amateur astronomer, [[Jon Culshaw]] on the second night. The final episode also included a feature titled the "Great Big Dulverton Switch Off" where every light in the town of [[Dulverton]], [[Somerset]] was switched off live on TV to highlight the issue of [[light pollution]]. Each episode of the series was immediately followed by ''Back to Earth'', an additional half-hour discussion of the main show. The second series was a co-production with the [[Open University]], with OU science consultants Dr Andrew Norton, Dr Dave Rothery and Dr Stephen Serjeant.{{cite news | url=http://www.open.edu/openlearn/whats-on/ou-on-the-bbc-stargazing-live | title=OU on the BBC: Stargazing LIVE | publisher=[[Open University]] | date=15 December 2011 | accessdate=9 February 2012}} During the 2012 series, viewers were encouraged to help locate possible [[exoplanets]], planets orbiting stars outside the [[Solar System]], by volunteering some time on the [[Planet Hunters]]{{cite web | url=http://www.planethunters.org | title=Planet Hunters | publisher=[[Zooniverse (citizen science project)|Zooniverse]] | accessdate=19 January 2012}} online [[citizen science]] project. This led to the discovery of a new [[Neptune]]-sized exoplanet by two amateur astronomers, one in [[Peterborough]], England, to be named [[Threapleton Holmes B]].{{cite news|last= |first= |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/space/9026837/Amateur-stargazers-discover-new-planet.html |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |title=Amateur stargazers discover new planet |publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]] |date=20 January 2012 |accessdate=20 January 2012}} The third series returned with another three episodes. As with the last series, a "Back to Earth" chat was held after each episode. A citizen science project was again featured, this time asking viewers to help in identifying areas of interest in aerial photographs of the surface of [[Mars]]. Another feature which ran across the three nights involved the construction of a modern version of [[William Herschel]]'s 20-foot telescope at the [[University of Derby]].{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ariel/20970167 | title=BBC builds William Herschel's telescope for Stargazing Live | publisher=BBC | date=10 January 2013}} The fourth series appeared in January 2014, with the citizen science project asking viewers to look for evidence of [[gravitational lensing]] in deep space photographs, which resulted in the discovery of dozens of previously unknown galaxies. The series also featured live broadcasts from Norway with the aim of capturing the [[aurora borealis]] on camera; although the show's publicity emphasised that the unpredictable nature of the aurora meant this attempt could easily fail, an unexpectedly large [[coronal mass ejection]] that week resulted in strong auroral activity, with live footage of the phenomenon being captured on all three nights. Stargazing Live returned in 2015 but it was not held in the usual January slot which has been the usual month for all previous events, it was held on 18 to 20 March instead to coincide with next total solar eclipse {{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/StargazingLive |title=BBC Stargazing LIVE |work=Facebook |date= |accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.redditchastro.org.uk/?p=1511 |title=BBC Stargazing Live 2015 |work=Redditch Astronomical Society |date= |accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.herts.ac.uk/bayfordbury/visit-bayfordbury-observatory/public-open-evenings |title=Bayfordbury Observatory: Public open evenings |work=University of Hertfordshire |date= |accessdate=25 March 2015}} which took place on 20 March 2015.{{cite web|url=http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEgoogle/SEgoogle2001/SE2015Mar20Tgoogle.html |title=Total Solar Eclipse of 2015 March 20 |work=Heliophysics Science Division, NASA |date= |accessdate=25 March 2015}} On 6 November 2015, the BBC confirmed two special episodes of ''Stargazing Live'' which aired on 15 December 2015, with Dara Ó Briain and Professor Brian Cox, covering the launch of [[Expedition 46]] to the [[International Space Station]] with British [[astronaut]] [[Tim Peake]] aboard. The first special entitled ''Blast Off Live: A Stargazing Special'' covered the launch of Expedition 46 at 11:05 am. A latter programme ''Stargazing Live Special: Tim Peake Docking'' covered the missions' docking with the ISS that same evening.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2015/bbc-tim-peake |title=Tim Peake - Britain’s first International Space Station astronaut – on the BBC |date= 6 November 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2015}} Simultaneously the BBC confirmed a sixth series of ''Stargazing Live'', which began in January 2016, featuring coverage of Tim Peake aboard the International Space Station. The seventh series of Stargazing Live was broadcast from Australia on March 18–20, 2017, taking advantage of the Equinox to match the last three-quarters of an hour of darkness in Australia or an 8:00pm broadcast time in the UK.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b019h4g8 |title=Stargazing Live |work=BBC Two |accessdate=6 April 2017}} ==Stargazing Live in Australia== In 2017, following on from the seventh series of BBC Stargazing Live in Australia, [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC TV]] broadcast an Australia-focused series on 4–6 April 2017, co-anchored by Brian Cox and Australian television presenter [[Julia Zemiro]] and featuring [[Kumi_Taguchi_(journalist)|''Kumi Taguchi'']]. The BBC Australian program was similar to the UK format, as the hosts were joined by professional astrophysicists such as [[Lisa Harvey-Smith]] and [[Chris Lintott]], amateur astronomer Greg Quicke, and Indigenous Australian Michael Anderson who shared the astronomical knowledge of Indigenous Australians and their connection with the cosmos. {{cite web |url=https://tv.press.abc.net.au/abc-presents-stargazing-live |title=ABC presents Stargazing Live |work=ABC |accessdate=3 January 2018}} A second Australian series aired on 22-24 May, 2018. It featured a Guinness World Record for the most people simultaneously observing an object in the night sky, when approximately 40,000 registered citizens watched the moon for 10 minutes on the 23rd May.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-05-24/stargazing-world-record-announcement/9797184 |title=Stargazing Live breaks world record for most people looking at the night sky at once |work=ABC |accessdate=25 May 2018}} == Episodes == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Series !! Episodes !! Start date !! End date !! UK viewers

of the [[Lovell Telescope]] at their HQ in [[Jodrell Bank Observatory]] and tries to experience what an astronaut does. |} ===Series 2 (2012)=== Each episode of this series was immediately followed by which telescopes amateurs should use, Liz Bonnin is at SALT in South Africa, and viewers are given the chance to find their own exo-planets. |- | '''2x02''' | 17 January 2012 |[[Black holes]] | Brian Cox explains how black holes are formed, Liz Bonnin is at SALT in South Africa, Mark Thompson takes four budding astronomers from the light polluted skies of London to a dark spot, Dara Ó Briain explains the live switch off, UFO's are explained and the team from the University run an animation to show the beginning of the Universe. |- | '''2x03''' | 18 January 2012 | [[Extraterrestrial life|Aliens]] | The team hunt for aliens, viewers discover a new planet, Dara Ó Briain and Brian Cox hear the sound of a far off object, Mark Thompson convinces a whole town to switch off their lights live, Liz Bonnin shows off South African telescopes, information about mankind deep in space is explained and Dara Ó Briain hears music from the Universe. |} ===Series 3 (2013)=== As with Series 2, each episode was followed by ''Stargazing Live: Back to Earth''. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Episode !Aired !Topic !Episode Summary |- | '''3x01''' | 8 January 2013 | [[Mars|Mars Exploration]] | Dara O Briain and Professor Brian Cox celebrate our amazing night sky. They kick things off with the search for evidence of life on Mars and ask viewers for help to explore an uncharted area of the red planet's surface. Liz Bonnin reports live from NASA mission control to find out the latest findings of the Curiosity Rover, whilst Mark Thompson offers tips on how to observe the moons of Jupiter. |- | '''3x02''' | 9 January 2013 | [[Outer space|Deep Space]] | Dara and Brian's journey through the night sky continues with a look into the distant past, explaining how it is possible to chart the history of the universe by looking million of light years out into the depths of space. Meanwhile, Mark Thompson reveals what can be learned from the colours of the stars. At NASA, Liz Bonnin meets the team building the largest space telescope in the world, an instrument that's 100 times more powerful than the Hubble. |- | '''3x03''' | 10 January 2013 |[[Meteors]], [[Asteroids]] & [[Comets]] | On the final night of their astronomical adventure, Brian and Dara discuss meteors, comets and asteroids and reveal how studying them reveals information about the origins of life on Earth. Meanwhile, Liz Bonnin meets the NASA team tasked with tracking any space objects on a collision course with Earth. The results of the experiment carried out by the Stargazing viewers - to explore an uncharted area on the surface of Mars - are also revealed. |} ===Series 4 (2014)=== As with Series 2 and 3, each episode was followed by ''Stargazing Live: Back to Earth''. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Episode !Aired !Topic !Episode Summary |- | '''4x01''' | 7 January 2014 | [[Aurora Borealis|Aurora Hunting]] | Dara O Briain and Professor Brian Cox explain how activity on the Sun distorts the Earth's magnetic field and creates the aurorae. The show coincided with a large [[coronal mass ejection]] which resulted in a spectacular display on the third night of the series. Liz Bonnin is in Tromso, Norway showing live pictures of the [[Aurora Borealis|aurora]]. Mark Thompson is in Norfolk with the local astronomical societies. [[Carolyn Porco]], head of the [[Cassini-Huygens|Cassini]] mission imaging team, is a guest at Jodrell Bank and they show Cassini movies of aurorae on Saturn. Viewers are invited to participate in examining 40,000 images of galaxies to identify galaxies which gravitationally lens light from far distant galaxies behind them - the aim was for 500,000 images to be examined in two days; in fact this target was met before the end of that evenings' "Stargazing Live: Back to Earth"! |- | '''4x02''' | 8 January 2014 | [[Human spaceflight|Space exploration]] | Dara and Brian are thrilled to have two of their heroes as guests tonight - Commander [[Walter Cunningham]] of [[Apollo 7]], and Commander [[Chris Hadfield]], former commander of the [[International Space Station]]. Liz Bonnin takes to the air to view the aurora from 30,000 feet, above the clouds in Norway. Mark Thompson explains how to view satellites in space from Earth. Dara experiences weightlessness on a "[[vomit comet]]" aircraft flight. |- | '''4x03''' | 9 January 2014 |[[Gravitational lens]]es & [[Galaxy|Galaxies]] | The search for hidden galaxies started on the first night has been extremely successful - more than 50 [[gravitational lens]]es were discovered in two days, and some of the worlds' largest telescopes have been tasked with verifying viewers' discoveries. Brian explains how we work out what the shape of our Galaxy looks like. Dara endures the G-forces experienced by astronauts during a launch in a training centrifuge. Mark Thompson demonstrates how to navigate a boat across the English Channel only using the stars. There is a discussion on [[exoplanets]]. |} ===Series 5 (2015)=== Stargazing Live 2015 was broadcast on 18, 19 and 20 March to coincide with the [[Solar eclipse of March 20, 2015|Solar eclipse of Friday 20 March 2015]] which - cloud permitting - was visible across much of Britain.{{cite web |title=Stargazing Live |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b019h4g8 |work=BBC |accessdate=21 February 2015}} The eclipse is comparable with the [[Solar eclipse of August 11, 1999|1999 Solar Eclipse]] in the Northern most parts of Britain and will be the last total solar eclipse visible in Europe until [[Solar eclipse of March 20, 2015|26 August 2026]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Episode !Aired !Topic !Episode Summary |- | '''5x01''' | 18 March 2015 | [[Moon|The Moon]] | Dara O Briain and Professor Brian Cox discuss the Apollo missions with [[Buzz Aldrin]], [[Dallas Campbell]] tests a [[telerobotics|telerobotic]] prototype at [[European Space Research and Technology Centre|ESTEC]], [[Joseph Gutheinz]] discusses stolen and missing moon rocks and Lucie Green presents a guide to things viewers can observe on the surface of the moon. |- | '''5x02''' | 19 March 2015 |[[Solar eclipse of March 20, 2015|Solar eclipse]] | Brian Cox and Dara O Briain are joined by Buzz Aldrin and Dr Matt Taylor, who discuss the [[European Space Agency]]'s [[Rosetta (spacecraft)|Rosetta]] mission after last year's groundbreaking touchdown on [[67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko|comet 67P]]. Dara also investigates whether asteroid mining may be possible in the future. Liz Bonnin reports from the [[Faroe Islands]] and explains how the solar eclipse will be filmed from above the clouds in an airplane. |- | '''5x03a''' | 20 March 2015 (morning) |[[Solar eclipse of March 20, 2015|Solar eclipse]] | Live coverage of the solar eclipse from Brian Cox and Dara O Briain. Liz Bonnin beams live pictures of the eclipse from a specially equipped plane. [[Chris Hollins]] is in the Faroe Islands to witness a total solar eclipse. Dr Lucie Green, Leah Boleto and hundreds of children carry out a nationwide experiment to see how the weather changes during the eclipse. |- | '''5x03b''' | 20 March 2015 (evening) |[[Solar eclipse of March 20, 2015|Solar eclipse]] |After the morning's solar eclipse, Brian Cox and Dara O Briain show images of the solar eclipse. Brian discusses the latest discoveries and solar secrets of [[Sun|the sun]], whilst Liz Bonnin discovers how a new generation of missions to the sun will fly closer than ever before. Dallas Campbell reports from European Space Agency's spacecraft test centre in the Netherlands to discover how sun-like conditions can be recreated on Earth. |} ===Series 6 (2016)=== A 6th series of ''Stargazing Live'' aired on 12–14 January 2016. Only one ''Back to Earth'' episode aired; it was broadcast following the first episode. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Episode !Aired !Topic !Episode Summary |- | '''6x01''' | 12 January 2016 | [[Tim Peake]], [[International Space Station|ISS]], [[Pulsar]]s | Tim Peake participates in an interview from the ISS. Brian and Dara test a [[gyroscope]] acting upon a garden shed. Liz Bonnin reports about [[John Bishop (comedian)|John Bishop]], who is participating in his first night of a recreation of Tim Peake's training programme, beginning in the [[Neutral buoyancy pool#ESA Neutral Buoyancy Facility .28NBF.29|ESA Neutral Buoyancy Facility]]. NASA scientist Carly Howett joins Dara and Brian to discuss some new images of [[Pluto]], taken by ''[[New Horizons]]''. Dara, Brian and [[Chris Lintott]] ask for audience help, searching for new [[pulsar]]s. Lucie Green discusses astronomy and how to photograph the ISS. |- | '''6x02''' | 13 January 2016 | [[Tim Peake]], [[International Space Station|ISS]] | Brian Cox and Dara O Briain report on the development of Tim Peake's six-month mission on the ISS and demonstrate the catastrophic impact that ordinary atmospheric pressure can have on a space ship. Liz Bonnin reports from the [[European Astronaut Centre]] in [[Cologne]], where John Bishop takes part in tests that astronauts take before going into space. |- | '''6x03''' | 14 January 2016 |[[Tim Peake]], [[International Space Station|ISS]], [[Pulsar]]s | Brian Cox and Dara O Briain return with further updates on Tim Peake's mission. They explore the technology on the ISS that is used to keep the astronauts safe. Liz Bonnin continues to report from the [[European Astronaut Centre]] in [[Cologne]], where John Bishop takes part in tests that astronauts take before going into space. Brian and Dara are joined in the studio by Dame Jocelyn Bell-Burnell, to hear how she discovered the first pulsar star. |} ===Series 7 (2017)=== Series 7 of Stargazing Live aired on 28–30 March 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/bbcstargazing/status/842359827548401664|title=BBC Stargazing Live on Twitter|website=Twitter|language=en|access-date=2017-03-16}}{{cite tweet |user=aussiestargazer |author=Donna Burton |number=806122707410681856 |date=21 November 2016 |title= Exciting news! Siding Spring Observatory will be hosting the UK television show Stargazing Live in March 2017 }} {{cite tweet |user=SkyatNightMag |author=Sky at Night Mag |number=806122707410681856 |date= 6 December 2016 |title= Hi, Stargazing Live in 2017 is scheduled for 28,29,30 March, but is always subject to change!}}. The series focused on stargazing and astronomy in [[Australia]], broadcast live from the [[Siding Spring Observatory]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/stayingin/tvfilm/stargazing-live-dara-o-briain-and-brian-cox-head-to-australia-for-another-view-of-the-night-sky-a3501421.html|title=Dara O Briain and Brian Cox head to Australia for Stargazing Live|date=2017-03-28|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en-GB}} For the first time, the series was followed by the first series of the Australian version of the show from 4–6 April 2017 on [[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-03-13/abc-open-stargazing-live/8339066|title=Australians share their view of the sky|date=2017-03-13|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en-AU}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Episode !Aired !Topic !Episode Summary |- | '''7x01''' |28 March 2017 |Stargazing in the southern hemisphere |Brian Cox, Dara O Briain, and Liz Bonnin broadcast live from Australia. Australian amateur astronomer Greg Quicke also joins the presenting team. They report on stargazing in the southern hemisphere and discuss how the stars have influenced Australian culture. Some of the topics include sun lines and the Southern Cross, which is part of the country's flag. Liz sets out to find a meteor which fell in the Australian bush. Viewers are also told about the effort to find [[Planet Nine]] and asked to help find the planet using [[Zooniverse]]. |- | '''7x02''' |29 March 2017 | [[Saturn]], [[Great Barrier Reef]] and the [[Moon]] |After the previous episode, stargazing and astronomy in Australia is reported on further. Greg Quicke explains how the moon is linked to the Great Barrier Reef. Despite the stormy weather, Greg and Liz are outside talking about Australian stargazing and show videos recorded earlier in the week. Dara and Brian discuss Saturn's rings and the science behind them. Dara also meets [[Sethu Vijayakumar]] to see robots which could be used to prepare Mars for people to travel to. |- | '''7x03''' |30 March 2017 |Stargazing in the southern hemisphere, Aliens, black holes |In the final episode of the series, more is reported on stargazing in the southern hemisphere. Brian discusses the black hole that can be found in the centre of the milky way galaxy and explains what a black hole really is. Dara looks into extra-terrestrial life and finds out what is being done to find other intelligent life forms. Liz continues on from Dara to talk about early life on earth and finds evidence hidden in rocks in Australia. |} ===Specials=== Two special episodes of ''Stargazing Live'' aired on 15 December 2015 to cover the launch of [[Tim Peake]] into space as part of [[Expedition 46]] to the [[International Space Station]]. A special aired on 15 January 2016 to celebrate Peake taking his first spacewalk. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Episode !Aired !Topic !Episode Summary |- | "Blast Off Live" | 15 December 2015 | [[Expedition 46]] Part 1 | The first part of the two-part special that covers the launch of [[Tim Peake]] into space as part of [[Expedition 46]] to the [[International Space Station]] |- | "Brit in Space" | 15 December 2015 | [[Expedition 46]] Part 2 | The second part of the two-part special that covers the launch of [[Tim Peake]] into space as part of [[Expedition 46]] to the [[International Space Station]] |- | "The Spacewalk" | 15 January 2016 | | Highlights from that day's [[Extravehicular activity|spacewalk]] featuring [[Tim Peake]], the first spacewalk performed by a British astronaut, with studio guest [[Chris Hadfield]]. |} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Portal|Cheshire}} *{{BBC programme}} [[Category:BBC Television programmes]] [[Category:Astronomy education television series]] [[Category:2011 British television programme debuts]]

page.title: The Rough Guide to True Crime

revision.text:
{{infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = The Rough Guide to True Crime | title_orig = | translator = | image = Rough Guide to True Crime cover.jpg | caption = | author = [[Cathy Scott]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States, United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = [[True crime]], [[Reference]] | publisher = [[Penguin Books]] | release_date = August 2009 | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages =336 pp | isbn = 978-1858283852 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Rough Guide to True Crime''''' is a non-fiction paperback reference guide to national and international true crime cases by American [[True crime|crime writer]] [[Cathy Scott]]. It was released in the UK and US in August 2009 by [[Penguin Books]] through its [[Rough Guides]] imprint.
== Summary == ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' is a compilation of a variety of cases, including historic crimes, with sections broken down by the type of offenses and who committed them. It includes black-and-white photos as illustration. Psychological profiles are included throughout by forensic expert Dr. Louis B. Schlesinger, who explains the psychology of serial killers, murderers, hit men and burglars.<ref>[http://www.waterstones.com/waterstonesweb/products/Cathy-Scott/The-Rough-Guide-to-True-Crime/6708060/ True crime Reviews: ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' (Book) by Cathy Scott (2009): reviews.waterstones.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The book features [[serial killer]] [[Jeffrey Dahmer]], mob hitman [[Richard Kuklinski|Richard "The Iceman" Kuklinski]], [[John Wayne Glover]] "The Granny Killer," and British "Doctor of Death" [[Harold Shipman]].
Scott's story from ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' about mob enforcer [[Herbert Blitzstein]] was selected for inclusion in the July 2012 retrospective of crime writing, ''[[Masters of True Crime|Masters of True Crime: Chilling Stories of Murder and the Macabre]]''.<ref>[http://www.thebigthrill.org/2012/07/masters-of-true-crime-by-r-barri-flowers-editor/ ''The Big Thrill'' magazine, "Masters of True Crime by R. Barri Flowers (Editor)"<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The author appeared on [[BlogTalkRadio]]'s "True Murder" show and described some of the crimes included in the book that were committed in the 19th century as "a different time in America, where people like [[Billy the Kid]] could walk in and just rob a bank" and get away with it. And while "there was nothing glamorous about what they did, they are a part of lore."<ref>[http://www.blogtalkradio.com/dan-zupansky1/2010/01/28/true-murder-episode-1-diane-fanning-baby-be-mine True Murder-Episode 3-Cathy Scott; ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' 01/27 by True Murder | Blog Talk Radio<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Critical reception == The book was featured at [[BookExpo America]] 2009's trade fair in [[Dorling Kindersley|DK Publishing]]'s booth in New York City.<ref>[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/trade-shows-events/article/14565-bookexpo-america-2009-around-the-bea-booths-c-d.html ''Publishers Weekly'': BookExpo America 2009: Around the BEA Booths: C - D<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In a review, ''[[True Crime Zine|True Crime Book Reviews]]'' wrote, "From the Moors murders and Harold Shipman, to the murder of 2pac, this guide illuminates the psychology in play behind the most intriguing crimes in history, from the absurd to the appalling. ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' explores the best of the haunting genre of True Crime."<ref>[http://truecrimebookreviews.blogspot.com/2009/05/new-true-crime-books-august-2009.html ''True Crime Book Reviews'': New True Crime Books August 2009<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Contents == *Outlaws: "The money, or your life" *Heists and Robberies *Kidnapped *White-collar Crime *Deception: The Art of the Con *Homicide *Serial Killers *Organized Crime *Dirty Cops and Bad Apples *Lesser Violations *Cybercrime
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.worldcat.org/title/rough-guide-to-true-crime/oclc/246886342&referer=brief_results ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' in libraries (WorldCat catalog)] * [http://www.roughguides.com/shop/rough-guide-true-crime/ebook/ Penguin's ''Rough Guide to True Crime'' book page] * [http://womenincrimeink.blogspot.com/2011/03/los-angeles-street-gangs-bloods-crips.html Book excerpt, "Los Angeles Street Gangs: Bloods & Crips"] * [https://www.amazon.com/Rough-Guide-True-Crime-Reference/dp/185828385X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1371709968&sr=1-1&keywords=the+rough+guide+to+true+crime Amazon's book page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rough Guide to True Crime, The}} [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:British non-fiction books]] [[Category:Non-fiction crime books]] [[Category:Penguin Press books]] [[Category:2009 books]] [[Category:Crime reference works]] [[Category:Universal history books]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about criminals]] [[Category:Books by Cathy Scott]] [[Category:Reference works]]
